keyFacts: The Federal Bureau of Prisons contracted with SigNet Technologies, Inc. for a $698,108.99 camera system at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York.
The contract was awarded on September 21, 2018, with a scheduled delivery date of September 28, 2018.
The contract includes extensive security and personnel vetting clauses, including compliance with Homeland Security Presidential Directive-12 (HSPD-12) for contractor personnel.
The document is a standard government procurement form (SF 1449) and does not directly mention Jeffrey Epstein, his associates, or related criminal activities.
The contract specifies that the 'FACILITIES MANAGER' at MCC New York is designated as the Contracting Officer's Representative (COR), though the individual's name is not provided in this excerpt.
The document is a standard DOJ contract clause detailing security requirements for contractors handling sensitive government information.
It defines terms like 'DOJ Information', 'Covered Information System', and 'Personally Identifiable Information (PII)'.
It mandates strict compliance with federal security standards (FISMA, NIST, FIPS) and requires an Authority to Operate (ATO) for any system processing DOJ data.
It establishes rapid breach notification timelines (1 hour for confirmed breaches, 72 hours for potential breaches) to the DOJ CO/COR or DOJ-CERT.
It includes specific prohibitions, such as barring non-U.S. citizens from accessing DOJ Information Systems without a waiver and restricting the use of contractor-owned portable media.
The document contains Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) contract clauses requiring compliance from all subcontractors and cloud service providers.
Contractor performance will be evaluated using the Department of Defense's Contractor Performance Assessment Reporting System (CPARS).
The contract includes Section 508 compliance requirements for electronic and information technology accessibility.
The contract prohibits awards to corporations convicted of felonies under federal law within the preceding 24 months or with unpaid federal tax liabilities.
The document references standard government contracting procedures and regulations (FAR, BOP clauses, Department of Justice requirements).
